markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

journalnow.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of the Winston-Salem Journal, a daily newspaper published in Winston-Salem, North Carolina.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The Winston-Salem Journal and Journalnow.com are owned by BH Media Group Inc., a subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway, a publicly traded company run by the billionaire investor Warren Buffett. BH Media Group owns more than 30 daily newspapers, including its flagship publication, The Omaha World-Herald, in Buffett’s hometown.

In July 2018, Lee Enterprises, a publicly traded newspaper chain that owns more than 40 daily newspapers across the country, began managing operations for BH Media’s newspapers under a partnership announced by the two companies. The website generates revenue through advertisements and paid subscriptions.

Content

The Journal covers local and national news, sports, business, and other topics relevant to the Winston-Salem area in northern and central North Carolina. The Briefcase features news about businesses and real estate. The Community section lists wedding announcements, obituaries, and classified ads. Wire services such as The Associated Press contribute national and international coverage.

In addition to the newspaper, the website features entertainment and lifestyle publications produced by the Journal. Relish, a weekly tabloid, provides information about upcoming concerts, local restaurants, and events. Winston-Salem Monthly, the Journal’s monthly magazine, publishes feature stories and profiles of local residents. The site also includes a semi-annual weddings publication, Carolina Weddings Magazine.

Credibility

A staff of reporters, photographers, and editors create content. Headlines are straightforward, factual, and reflect the content of stories. Photography is attributed to sources. The Journal consistently uses firsthand interviews and references primary source documents in its reporting. Editorial and opinion sections are clearly distinguished from news.

The Journal won 11 first-place awards and placed second in General Excellence in the 2017 News, Editorial & Photojournalism Contest sponsored by the North Carolina Press Association, including prizes for feature writing and beat reporting.

Although there is no corrections policy on the site, the Journal regularly corrects errors in stories on the website.

Transparency

The website provides the names of reporters and a comprehensive directory of editorial and senior staff, with emails and phone numbers. Biographical information about staff is not available, although the names of story authors link to social media profiles, emails, and an archive of the author’s work. Advertisements are clearly labeled.

History

In 1971, The Journal won a Pulitzer Prize in the Public Service category for overage of a successful environmentalist campaign to block a mining operation in the hill country of northwest North Carolina.

The Journal typically supports Republican candidates. The publication’s endorsement in 2012 of Barack Obama represented the first time it had backed a Democratic candidate for president since Lyndon Johnson in 1964. The Journal endorsed Libertarian Gary Johnson for president in 2016. The website was registered in 1996.

Written by:
Evan Haddad

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Jim Warren
